@LefterisJP @ENS_DAO @BrantlyMillegan This is amazing. They way you‚Äôre handling this sets an example for those holding a large delegation of votes. üëè

With tragedy and global instability in our headlines, this should be more apparent than ever.

Recognizing your own humanity in others is easiest in the communities that you already belong to. Let‚Äôs start here, CT.

Let‚Äôs all do better. 

The Crypto Twitter feedback loop of pre-planned sh*posts to farm engagement produces factionalism & toxic negativity.

We‚Äôre all here because we believe in a brighter future. Unlike legacy frameworks, that future doesn‚Äôt need to be inherently exclusionary.
@areeve @theweb3god @matthewegould Glad to have you!

@matthewegould The irony is that your post was straight out of the dirty politician playbook. Unfortunate.

The week before ETHDenver we had decided to postpone the vote until the 28th, which I'm sure is in Discord DMs or Google Meet records.

@matthewegould Less concerned about your uninformed post than your disrespect for people losing their lives in a war right now. 

You just falsely claimed that the ENS team used a war to hide a vote against Brantly. The timing of the two events is demonstrably and absolutely unrelated.

RT @spencecoin: this is a pretty gross tweet

go read the weeks of discussion on the ens forums to see that there's no weird timing about t‚Ä¶

Bad look.

@ottodv It‚Äôs healthy for the DAO to have a large pool of actively voting delegates. 

This helps ensure voting power remains effectively distributed, preserving the decentralization of power.

Check out this forum post:
https://t.co/KAlATnczfO

Centralization of voting power post: https://t.co/KAlATnczfO

Delegate Applications: https://t.co/63IMKLF8hi

On-Chain Voting:
https://t.co/52yysz48Cr

https://t.co/w6rV5KoLa4

Why is this important? Having a wide distribution of delegations prevents the ENS DAO voting power from becoming too centralized.

@spencecoin If there's one point of unity here, it's that we all care and we're reevaluating the state of things.

This needs to happen if we want to become better people and grow as organizations.
RT @Coltron_eth: @LefterisJP @Sim_Pop @zherring @lex_node @ENS_DAO @LefterisJP The DAO is not diminished.  We still have an important voice‚Ä¶

@LefterisJP @Sim_Pop @zherring @lex_node @ENS_DAO Yes,‚òùÔ∏è we need those discussions. 

We're all questioning different aspects of the recent events. If there's one point of unity here it's that we all care and that we're reevaluating the state of things. This needs to happen if we want to be better people and an organization.

@LefterisJP @Sim_Pop @zherring @lex_node @ENS_DAO @LefterisJP Our collective bandwidth for all of this is being depleted, and it's easy to grow tired of this and wonder, what's the point? 

I want to encourage everyone to reflect on how much we individually care about this topic. For different reasons, it's still significant.

@LefterisJP @Sim_Pop @zherring @lex_node @ENS_DAO @LefterisJP The DAO is not diminished.  We still have an important voice. We have the responsibility to determine how Brantly remains involved in the DAO.

Irrespective of which way anyone leans, I would encourage everyone to take part in governance now, when it matters most.

@LefterisJP @Sim_Pop @zherring @lex_node @ENS_DAO @LefterisJP With TNL's decision to terminate him, this does steer the discussion quite a bit. Ultimately, Brantly role as DoO with TNL is separate from his role as one of the three Directors with The ENS Foundation, which is the legal entity for the DAO.

@LefterisJP @Sim_Pop @zherring @lex_node @ENS_DAO @LefterisJP üëã Hey! The Community Stewards voted to remove Brantly indefinitely from his position as a Community Steward. We felt that this was necessary considering the response from the community. With that, we hoped to invoke the DAO for a DAO-wide discussion and response.
